subject: Re: [junit] The upcoming "assert" keyword in JDK 1.4

messageBody:
Yeah, I had some converstaions with Sun folks about that. Thing is, that I
didn't find their arguments compelling and they basically brushed off the
alternatives that were presented to them. We have a particularly
functional assertion package that doesn't require a keyword, and although:

Assert.assertion(y < 0);

is a little more verbose than:

assert: y < 0;

When you look at the additional flexibility and code clarity of a class:

Assert.notNull(foo);
Assert.checkParam(y < 0); (throws an IllegalArgumentException)
Assert.checkState(state, OPEN); (throws an InvalidStateException)

the JDK 1.4 approach loses out. The arguments that they needed it to
be a keyword so that they could produce better diagnostics also doesn't
float. They could have created a special class with some additional
compiler Magic, just like String, Class, Thread, and so forth,
without adding a new keyword, let alone a new syntactic production. I
think that if they had bothered to explore options they could have found
a viable one. Our package is just one of a large number that found a way
to support assertions without changing the language.

In any case, the damage is done, so there is probably no point in
continuing to argue. I do appreciate the addition of the feature; I just
think that they were a little heavy handed with the implementation of what
should have been a minor change. It makes me wonder how much they will
break with the new generics support that's in the works.

Your sed suggestion is a good one. I've started hacking out a Perl script.
One problem I have is comming up with a logical package name to replace
"com.qlue.util.assert". I suppose I could use "assertions" as it will only
be in the imports statement and the length doesn't matter much.

On Wed, 3 Oct 2001, S. J. Stremler wrote:

> Eric Vought wrote:
> >
> > "assert" has been deprecated in JUnit, replaced by assertTrue().
> >
> > <rant>Of course, that still leaves hundreds of existing references to
> > change (per project), but Sun didn't appear to care, even though it was
> > hardly necessary for them to make it a reserved word, much less add a new
> > gramattical production to the language. It's worse for use, since we have
> > a support package named "assert" which all of our packages depend on, so
> > we can't just deprecate a single method.
> >
> > It always amazes me when folks go through the trouble to create a nice,
> > object oriented language with hierarchical namespaces and can't figure
> > out how to add a feature without modifying the syntax.
> > </rant>
> >
> > OK, I feel a little better.
>
> Um, find, grep, and sed are your friends.
>
> Something like (on a fresh copy of your source tree(s) in case it breaks):
>
> find $directory -name '*.java' -exec fgrep -l '\.assert\.' {} \; > targets
> foreach i ( cat targets )
> mv $i ${i}.save
> sed -e 's/\.assert\./.Assert./' < ${i}.save > $i
> end
>
> ....should take care of much of the work, no? YMMV, of course.
>
> The folks at Sun made a good case (at JavaOne 2001) for why it needs to
> be a keyword. And "assert" is the most useful keyword to use -- in the
> long run, it's better to bite the bullet and deal with an improved
> language rather than letting random developers contort the language
> into something convenient for them but less clear for everyone else.
> After all, 1.3.x will be around for some time yet.
>
> 1.4 is in beta at the moment, so you still have time to devise a new
> packaging scheme, deprecate the old one, and convince everyone who uses
> your stuff to change.
>
>
